skills.name: Calculate the cube of a number
Calculate the square root of a number
Raise a positive integer to a positive integer power
Multiplication law of indices with positive integer powers and a different base number

explanations.A: Almost, but your calculator uses bidmas so will square the 7 and then make it negative if you use method 1
explanations.B: Not quite. Your calculator uses bidmas so will square the 7 and then make it negative if you use method 1
explanations.C: Not quite. Squaring a number means you multiply two copies of the number together, we don't multiply the number by 2
explanations.D: Both 2 and 3 are correct. We need to consider BIDMAS when using a calculator.

explanations.A: Almost, but your calculator uses bidmas so will square the 3 and then make it negative if you use method 3
explanations.B: Both 1 and 2 will give the correct answer as your calculator will use BIDMAS.
explanations.C: Not quite. Squaring a number means you multiply two copies of the number together, we don't multiply the number by 2
explanations.D: Not quite. Your calculator uses bidmas so will square the 3 and then make it negative if you use method 3

explanations.A: I think you have just subtracted 12 from 15. You need to work out the squares, subtract them and then find the square root
explanations.B: I think you doubled the numbers rather than squaring them. Remember when you square a number you multiply two copies of the number together
explanations.D: Almost, I think you divided by 2 rather than square rooting.

explanations.A: We have 13² - 12² = 169 - 144 = 25, then the square root of 25 is 5.
explanations.B: Almost, I think you divided by 2 rather than square rooting.
explanations.C: I think you have just subtracted 12 from 13. You need to work out the squares, subtract them and then find the square root
explanations.D: I think you doubled the numbers rather than squaring them. Remember when you square a number you multiply two copies of the number together

explanations.A: 4² ✕ 2² is the same as 4 ✕ 4 ✕ 2 ✕ 2 = 16 ✕ 4 = 64. So Tom is correct. Alternatively, because both the 4 and 2 are being squared, we could rewrite this as (4 ✕ 2)² = 8², not 8⁴ so Katie is incorrect
explanations.B: Not quite. Try working out each power to see if the answers match
explanations.C: At least one person is incorrect. Try working out each power to see if the answers match
explanations.D: At least one person is correct. Try working out each power to see if the answers match

explanations.A: Not quite. Try working out each power to see if the answers match
explanations.B: 3² ✕ 4² is the same as 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 4 ✕ 4 = 9 ✕ 16 = 144. This is 12², so Jo is incorrect. Alternatively, because both the 3 and 4 are being squared, we could rewrite this as (3 ✕ 4)² = 12² so Paul is correct
explanations.C: At least one person is incorrect. Try working out each power to see if the answers match
explanations.D: At least one person is correct. Try working out each power to see if the answers match

explanations.B: Almost, I think you found the powers correctly but added them by mistake. Remember we are multiplying the answers
explanations.C: I think you multiplied the number by the power rather than raising to the power. Remember a power of 3 means you are multiplying 3 copies of the number together
explanations.D: I think you multiplied the number by the power rather than raising to the power. Remember a power of 3 means you are multiplying 3 copies of the number together

explanations.B: Almost, I think you worked out the powers correctly but then added them. The question asks you to multiply them together
explanations.C: I think you multiplied the numbers by the powers. Remember 3³ means you have 3 copies of 3 multiplied together, so 3 x 3 x 3.
explanations.D: Not quite, this is 3⁴. Work out 3³ first, then 2² and then multiply them together

explanations.A: Not quite, try writing out the powers of 5: 5, 25, 125, 625...
explanations.B: Not quite. Try writing out the powers of 2: 2, 4, 8, 16, 32....
explanations.C: Thinking about the powers of 2, we have 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64, 128, 256… In this sequence, each number is multiplied by 2 to get the next number. Look at the last digit: as no numbers end with the digit 5 (which they wouldn’t because they are all even), there will never be a situation where 2^m ends in 0. Similarly, powers of 5 are 5, 25, 125, 10625. The last digit is always 5, and multiplying this by 5 to get the next digit will always result in a last digit of 5.
explanations.D: At least one person is correct. Try writing out the powers of 5: 5, 25, 125, 625... and 2: 2, 4, 8, 16....

explanations.A: Not quite. Try writing out the powers of 4: 4, 16, 64...
explanations.B: Not quite. Try writing out the powers of 3: 3, 9, 27 ....
explanations.C: Thinking about the powers of 3, we have 3, 9, 27, 81, 243… In this sequence, each number is multiplied by 3 to get the next number. There will always be a situation where an odd number is being multiplied by 3, another odd number. This will always give rise to another odd number. For Paul’s statement, powers of 4 are 4, 16, 64, 256, 1024. The last digit is always 4 or 6, meaning he is also correct.
explanations.D: At least one person is correct. Try writing out the powers of 3: 3, 9, 27... and 4: 4, 16, 64...
